title: 112_s2080
content: The Act titled "Keeping Families in their Home Act of 2012" allows banks to lease foreclosed properties. The "Keeping Families in their Home Act of 2012" permits depository institutions or affiliates to lease residential properties that were security for a loan for up to 5 years. The "Keeping Families in their Home Act of 2012" allows depository institutions or affiliates to lease foreclosed properties despite any federal or state laws restricting property holding or leasing. Federal banking agencies will jointly create safety and soundness regulations. The federal banking agencies will establish regulations for leasing activities of depository institutions or affiliates to ensure safety and soundness, including minimum capital requirements and appropriate actions to protect capital and soundness. The Keeping Families in their Home Act of 2012 allows depository institutions or affiliates to hold property for up to 5 years, with the possibility of extension based on relevant laws. This section applies only to leases entered into within a 3-year period from the enactment date. The Keeping Families in their Home Act of 2012 allows depository institutions to hold property for up to 5 years, with the possibility of extension. Congress intends no permanent policy change on leasing foreclosed property for depository institutions. SEC. 3 of the Keeping Families in their Home Act of 2012 allows government-sponsored enterprises like Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to lease foreclosed properties for up to 5 years to mitigate losses and stabilize home prices. The authority to enter into leasing agreements will expire 3 years after the enactment of the Act.
